claim: The human brain contains 10 billion neurons.

supporting.text: The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons, as established by modern neuroscience research.

attacks.text: The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons, as established by modern neuroscience research.
Early estimates of neuron count were based on less accurate measurement techniques, leading to the misconception of 10 billion neurons.
Modern stereological counting methods have consistently confirmed the 86 billion neuron count, refuting older estimates.
Some regions of the brain, like the cerebellum, contain a disproportionately high number of neurons, which might skew total counts.
Even accounting for regional variations, the total neuron count across all brain regions still averages to approximately 86 billion.

supporting.text: Neuroscientific studies using stereological counting methods confirm that the human brain has significantly more than 10 billion neurons.

attacks.text: Neuroscientific studies using stereological counting methods confirm that the human brain has significantly more than 10 billion neurons.
Early estimates of neuron counts were based on less accurate methods, leading to the 10 billion figure being widely cited in older literature.
Modern stereological methods have been validated and are considered the gold standard for neuron counting, making older estimates obsolete.
Neuron counts can vary significantly between individuals due to genetic and environmental factors, making any single estimate potentially misleading.
While individual variation exists, stereological studies provide average estimates that are robust across large populations.

supporting.text: The cerebral cortex alone contains roughly 16 billion neurons, which already exceeds the claimed total of 10 billion.

attacks.text: The cerebral cortex alone contains roughly 16 billion neurons, which already exceeds the claimed total of 10 billion.
The claim may refer to non-cortical regions of the brain, which have fewer neurons, bringing the total closer to 10 billion when excluding the cortex.
Even non-cortical regions like the cerebellum contain tens of billions of neurons, making a total of 10 billion for the entire brain highly unlikely.
The 16 billion figure for the cortex might be an overestimation due to methodological differences in neuron counting.
Modern stereological methods consistently confirm the 16 billion estimate for the human cerebral cortex, with high reproducibility across studies.

supporting.text: Comparative neuroanatomy shows that even smaller primate brains contain more than 10 billion neurons, making the claim implausible for humans.

attacks.text: Comparative neuroanatomy shows that even smaller primate brains contain more than 10 billion neurons, making the claim implausible for humans.
The claim refers specifically to the human brain, not primate brains in general, and may account for variations in neuron density.
Neuron counts in primate brains are highly correlated with brain size, and human brains are significantly larger than those of smaller primates.
Neuron density can vary widely even among species with similar brain sizes, making direct comparisons unreliable.

supporting.text: Peer-reviewed studies using modern imaging and cell counting techniques consistently report neuron counts in the human brain that are an order of magnitude higher than 10 billion.

attacks.text: Peer-reviewed studies using modern imaging and cell counting techniques consistently report neuron counts in the human brain that are an order of magnitude higher than 10 billion.
Some older studies and simplified educational materials still cite the 10 billion neuron figure, creating confusion and outdated references.
Modern neuroscience has largely discredited older neuron counts due to improved methodologies and larger sample sizes, making the 10 billion figure obsolete.
Neuron counts can vary significantly between individuals due to genetic and environmental factors, making precise universal estimates difficult.
Despite individual variability, large-scale studies show a consistent average neuron count far exceeding 10 billion, with tight statistical confidence intervals.
